intro_bio: Hi, I’m Romeo De Timmerman, a researcher at Ghent University combining sociolinguistic and computational approaches to study language in popular culture.

bio: I obtained my master’s degree in English and Dutch linguistics and literature from Ghent University in 2020. Since then, I have worked on projects involving language, identity, and media, and have taught at both undergraduate and graduate levels. In 2022, I began my PhD at Ghent University, investigating the stylistic use of African American English by blues performers. More recently, I have expanded my research interests to include computational linguistics, machine learning, and natural language processing. Alongside completing my PhD, I am currently pursuing a master’s in Statistical Data Analysis, with a focus on deep learning and natural language processing.

project_items.description: Modeling formant trajectories of PRICE vowels using feature engineering, dimensionality reduction, gradient boosted decision trees, and neural networks. This project applies interpretable machine learning to explore gradient vowel production and categorical perception.

Predicting the presence of African American English features in blues singing using gradient boosted decision trees. This project combines machine learning and sociolinguistics to examine patterns of linguistic variation in musical performance.
